links: I. M. Gessel, Applications of the classical umbral calculus, arXiv:math/0108121 [math.CO], 2001.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} (-2)^(n-k)*stirling2(n, k). - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Apr 04 2003From _Peter Bala_, May 16 2012: (Start)Recurrence equation: a(n+1) = sum {k = 0..n} (-2)^(n-k)*C(n,k)*a(k). Written umbrally this is a(n+1) = (a-2)^n (expand the binomial and replace a^k with a(k)). More generally, a*f(a) = f(a-2) holds umbrally for any polynomial f(x). An inductive argument then establishes the umbral recurrence a*(a+2)*(a+4)*...*(a+2*(n-1)) = 1 with a(0) = 1. Cf. A004211.Touchard's congruence holds for odd prime p: a(p+k) = (a(k) + a(k+1)) (mod p) for k = 0,1,2, ... (adapt the proof of Theorem 10.1 in Gessel). In particular, a(p) = 2 (mod p) for odd prime p.(End)G.f.: (1/E(0)-1)/x  where E(k)=  1 - x/(1 - 2*x + 2*x*(k+1)/E(k+1)); (continued fraction, 2-step). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Sep 21 2012G.f.: 1 +x/G(0) where G(k)= 1 + 2*x/(1 + 1/(1 + 4*x*(k+1)/G(k+1))); (continued fraction, 3-step). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Nov 21 2012G.f.: (G(0) - 1)/(x-1) where G(k) = 1 - 1/(1+x*2*k)/(1-x/(x-1/G(k+1) )); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jan 16 2013G.f.: 1/Q(0) where Q(k)= 1 - x/(1 + 2*x*(k+1)/Q(k+1) ); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Apr 14 2013G.f.: Q(0)/(1-x), where Q(k) = 1 - 2*x^2*(k+1)/( 2*x^2*(k+1) + (1-x+2*x*k)*(1+x+2*x*k)/Q(k+1) ); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Oct 24 2013Lim sup n->infinity (abs(a(n))/n!)^(1/n) / (2*abs(exp(1/LambertW(-2*n)) / LambertW(-2*n))) = 1. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Aug 04 2014a(n) = (-2)^n*B_n(-1/2), where B_n(x) is n-th Bell polynomial. - _Vladimir Reshetnikov_, Oct 20 2015
mathematica: With[{nn=30},CoefficientList[Series[Exp[Sinh[x]/Exp[x]],{x,0,nn}],x]Range[0,nn]!] (* _Harvey P. Dale_, Jan 07 2013 *)Table[(-2)^n BellB[n, -1/2], {n, 0, 20}] (* _Vladimir Reshetnikov_, Oct 20 2015 *)
